column1: Gout is a type of arthritis.
Chronic gout is the repeated episodes of pain and inflammation.
People who take certain medicines, such as hydrochlorothiazide and other water pills, may have a higher level of uric acid in the blood.
People will have no symptoms after a first gout attack.
Many people will have another attack in the next 6 to12 months.
Some people may develop chronic gout.
People with chronic gout will have joint pain and other symptoms most of the time.
Tophi can develop after a person has had gout for many years.
Take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen, naproxen, or indomethacin when symptoms begin.
- A prescription medicine called colchicine helps reduce pain, swelling, and inflammation.
Your provider may inject the inflamed joint with steroids to relieve the pain.
You may need to take daily medicines such as allopurinol (Zyloprim), febuxostat (Uloric) or probenecid (Benemid) to decrease the uric acid level in your blood.
Complications may include: - Chronic gouty arthritis - Kidney stones - Deposits in the kidneys, leading to chronic kidney failure
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of acute gouty arthritis.
You may not be able to prevent gout, but you may be able to avoid things that trigger symptoms.
